Posts.Content: Apr 16, 2015 12:39PM inks wrote: It's great that you have your mammogram scheduled, I hope your insurance approves it soon. My situation was very similar to yours. I always had trouble feeding my baby on right side and when I stopped breastfeeding I noticed lumps. I assumed they were clogged ducts. I kept feeling hot constantly too, but I had thyrotoxicosis after the birth of my daughter so I am not sure if my cancer and night sweats were related, though they did continue even after my thyroid condition normalized. 6 months later I got a little dent in my breast and I went to my PCP. The rest is history. Since you are young and recently breastfed it is likely that your problems are not caused by cancer but you made a good decision by getting a mammogram. If your mammogram comes back negative you should ask your PCP to check your thyroid levels. Do you have family history of breast cancer? I hope your mammo is negative. Hugs!

Posts.Content: Sep 24, 2015 04:29PM inks wrote: Homeschool - the feelings and fears about dying are normal at this stage of the game but they will subside at some point. You just have to go through all the stages yourself and mull it over. I was wondering too why would god let such a thing happen to me while I had a 18 month old at home. But things just happen.... The fact that you have papillary carcinoma makes everything even more unusual. And I just notice that you are er- but pr+ that is unusual as well. I hope your doctors have experience with pregnancy and breast cancer or at least are consulting with someone who does. There was a lady on the chemo board one month ahead of me who was pregnant but she did chemo first and had the surgery after she delivered her healthy baby. I don't understand how it works but maybe some drugs do not cross over to the baby. I have my fingers crossed that you and the baby will pull through this and live happily ever after!

Posts.Content: Sep 26, 2016 07:10PM inks wrote: So sorry that they are making you to wait so long for your biopsy results. They took several biopsy samples because you had many areas of concern and they wanted to make sure the got some of those areas in their sample. I had 3 core samples. The enlarged lymph nodes are certainly a concern but you should wait for the biopsy results first. My enlarged node ended up having only micromets and an infection could also cause enlarged nodes. Waiting is the worst and I wish they would have told you at least the preliminary results rather than keep you waiting. If they use electronic medical records then you might be able to access your local biopsy results, they are your results and you have the right to know. Try to hang on until Thursday.

Posts.Title: What happens after radiotherapy mandm43 mandm43

Posts.Content: Apr 19, 2015 08:45AM inks wrote: It's great that you already saw doctors, it's a great idea to have things checked out. Inflammatory BC is very aggressive, it can advance dramatically in just one week, my friends IBC became very obvious and easy to diagnose within one week. The fact that you have had symptoms for 5 moths is a good indicator that you have something else going on. But it's a good idea to see breast specialist to figure out what is going on with you. A breast MRI might be overkill but if they find something concerning they will do an US, you could ask specifically if they can explain what is going on with your underarm lymphnodes since you complain of pain there. Could the bursitis have inflamed your lymphnodes? What treatment did you get for bursitis?
Posts.Title: 22 and inflammatory breast cancer? PLEASE HELP! Eleanorebelle inks

Posts.Content: Mar 16, 2015 07:21AM inks wrote: I was 36 with two micromets in one node, LVI and necrosis, bilateral mastectomy and opted to do rads. It was a hard decision sine based on my research it had only about 5% benefit for me. I barely burned (my RO has a protocol of curcumin that she did a study on) but my implant on that side is way hard and I have to go back to have it lowered. I did not want to look back and regret not doing it all. It may help you if you base your decision on your ER+ as well. I was 75% er+ and pr-, so I was not too sure that hormone treatment would be real effective on me. Good luck deciding.

Do you have family history of breast or ovarian cancer?

Posts.Content: Sep 1, 2016 02:18PM inks wrote: Show your doctors this study and ask for a consult with radiation oncologist. http://www.redjournal.org/article/S0360-3016(12)01428-9/fulltext#sec3 Conclusions MF/MC disease is significantly associated with at least double the risk of local recurrence, even after accounting for type of surgery and omission of RT or hormonal therapy. This study suggests that such patients may benefit from additional therapy to improve LC and thus perhaps should be considered for RT after mastectomy. Further study is required. Here is a study that finds poorer outcome with multifocal multicentric tumors http://bmcsurg.biomedcentral.com/articles/10.1186/1471-2482-15-1 Our results indicate that MF/MC cancers have a negative impact on prognosis and are related to higher loregional and distant relapse independently from the type of surgery performed. Adjuvant therapies did not modify the poorer outcome, but in patients receiving adjuvant anthacyclines, the differences with unicentric tumors were reduced. Our data support the hypothesis that MF/MC tumors may have a worse biological behavior and that the presence of multiple foci should be considered in planning adjuvant treatments.
Posts.Title: Feels too easy Mom2fourplusmore inks

Posts.Content: Aug 31, 2016 09:58AM inks wrote: I had 18 tumors and I got the same talk. However the hospital that I had radiation at did upstage me because of the overall tumor load. You should talk to a radiation onc since mine told me that with multifocal and multicentric you need radiation even after mastectomy. I saw two rad oncs and they both agreed. And yes it is mindblowing that there will be no tests or scans after breast cancer just waiting for symptoms. Some places however will do scans with ILC since it is so hard to detect. I never had a bone scan and I am stage IIb or IIIa. I was told I could not have OncoDX because hey would have to test all tumors and that would be too expensive. But some women do get it with multifocal tumors but they test only one. Some women even pay for the testing themselves.

Posts.Content: Jul 18, 2015 10:00PM inks wrote: So sorry you have to be here and sorry that your mom passed from breast cancer. I was 36 as well when diagnosed with a 18 month old. I know you are worried about mets but given your young age even if you would have mets they would treat your mets aggressively. Oligometastatic disease is treated "curatively" in someone as young as you. And it's just the nature of the beast that we younger ones get the more aggressive cancers, which by the way are more treatable by chemo. I hope they have referred you to genetic counseling. Hugs and good luck! You'll get through this!
Posts.Title: Just scared like everyone else :( sbeddows SlowDeepBreaths

Posts.Content: Apr 19, 2015 06:06PM inks wrote: So sorry that you lost your baby. But that may actually be a piece to your puzzle. My breast cancer was found after I stopped breastfeeding so I looked into the postpartum breast cancer stuff and apparently there is major changes going on in breast during that time: "Breast tissues undergo massive transformations during pregnancy in preparation for nursing the new infant. After milk production has ended, there is a cascade of cell death. "This cell death removes about 90 percent of breast epithelial cells during a very short window of time, which triggers widespread remodeling and repair of breast tissue by the immune system," explained Cook. During this remodeling, immune cells called macrophages operate like tiny Pac-Man arcade game characters, gobbling up the dying cells before the dying cells can release intracellular contents which can provoke immune attack. As another safeguard against immune attack, macrophages that 'eat' dying cells also secrete immune suppressive factors. Macrophages use one molecule — MerTK — to control both of those processes." http://news.vanderbilt.edu/2014/10/potential-therapy-for-postpartum-breast-cancer-investigated/ Have any of the doctors you've seen considered it to be connected with recently giving birth. If you look into the postpartum breast cancer reaserch and articles they keep mentioning the "wound healing process" that is going on after you stop breastfeeding and the cells die off. Could you have an inflammatory reaction to those milk producing cells dieing off? You need to see a doctor who is familiar with breast issues and can solve your 5 month long puzzle.
Posts.Title: 22 and inflammatory breast cancer? PLEASE HELP! Eleanorebelle inks

Posts.Content: May 31, 2015 11:46AM inks wrote: My lumps were tiny pea size but just felt icky. I had trouble feeding my baby from that breast from the start, inverted nipple for the first time in my life and baby refusing to feed from that breast. If you look up postpartum breast cancer they mention baby refusing to eat from affected breast as a common feature. They may tell you to wait 3-4 weeks and see if the lumps resolve on their own. If they are still there after 1 month try to get a mammo or ultrasound. Feed or pump immediately before and don't let them tell you that you need to stop breastfeeding for any testing. You don't want to risk stopping breastfeeding in case it turns out to be nothing (breastfeeding may help prevent breast cancer). Good luck and please come back here and let us know how it went!
Posts.Title: Two tiny lumps while breastfeeding-NOT mastitis aussigyrl aussigyrl

Posts.Content: Sep 1, 2014 05:26AM inks wrote: If the margins are not clear they usually like to do another surgery. The recommendation if you would need chemo depends also if they had Oncotype DX done and are waiting for results. It costs twice as much to test your 2 lesions.Â They didn't even try to do the test on me because the insurance company would have never agreed to test all my tumors. Â I was 36 when diagnosed and they told me that my age, grade of the tumorÂ and the fact that I had multifocal and multicentric tumors was a big factor for me getting chemo (but I had other stuff going on as well). Multifocal/multicentric tumors are tricky as to the way they are measured as well. The place I had my chemo went by my largest lesion, 2.1cm and put me in stage IIb. But the place I had my radiation at measured them all together and that put me at 5+cm and at stage IIIa. Since they are measuring your ones together that gives you a fairly large lesion, the cutoff for getting radiation after mastectomy is 4cm (if I remember it right). Just try to prepare yourself for the worst, chemo is not too bad.
Posts.Title: Skin sparing mastectomy done...but maybe some cells left behind Amber555 Amber555

Posts.Content: Sep 3, 2015 04:57PM inks wrote: So sorry you have lost your mom to breast cancer. Radiation after mastectomy is generally indicated for positive margins, lympho vasular invasion, extranodal extension, no axillary clearance, tumor close to chest wall, skin involment, multifocal or multicentric disease (there may be some other reasons, I am not a doctor). Radiation can minimize only locoregional failure. Did your mom have a locoregional failure (recurrence near the breast) before she was found to have metastatic disease?

Posts.Title: Waiting MRI results bllshane bllshane

Posts.Content: Feb 8, 2014 11:53AM inks wrote: I had a bilateral mastectomy with immediate delayed reconstruction (they put in the tissue expanders at the time of mastectomy and you will have another surgery to get implants put in). I chose this reconstruction because I have a 2 year old baby and the recovery is longer with the reconstructions where they use your own tissue. I was out of the hospital in less than 24 hours from the beginning of the surgery. You would have to see if they would recommend a skin or nipple sparing with being BRCA1+, I had no choice because I had 18 tumors, but prophylactic mastectomy is a whole different issue. And keep in mind you would still have to continue your ovarian cancer screenings. I am so close to being 40 years old I might just get my ovaries out next year.
Posts.Title: BRCA-1 Positive: To Do or Not Do Something Preventative Bearhitch Itiswhatitis2

Posts.Content: Feb 8, 2014 11:28AM inks wrote: I am BRCA1+ and would have loved to be in your position to do early screenings even if they are accompanied with increased anxiety. But you should not simply base the decision to do prophylactic mastectomy on one lump scare. Try to go and have a consultation with your genetic counselor or other professional again. You should not have surgery just because you are scared, you need to base it on the facts and benefits to you. But if you feel like screening is not enough for you and you do want to take more active measures a consultation with a breast surgeon and a plastic surgeon would be a place to start. As far as cost is concerned - you are already dealing with the cost of the screenings. If you end up leaning towards mastectomy you really need to seriously consider reconstruction and the studies about quality of life, self image and all the emotional effectsÂ  - and again your surgeon would be most helpful to discuss the benefits of reconstruction. While all surgeries have risks my own experience so far has been that at the age of 37 mastectomy and reconstruction have been fairly painless and easy. And try to find a high volume breast center hospital. I wish you the best of luck with your tough decsisions!
Posts.Title: BRCA-1 Positive: To Do or Not Do Something Preventative Bearhitch Itiswhatitis2

Posts.Content: May 5, 2015 09:19PM inks wrote: How did they assess the rate of growth/risk of recurrence with an MRI?
Posts.Title: Confirmed BC today and having bilateral mastectomy next week AngelLynn inks

Posts.Content: Nov 10, 2015 09:56PM inks wrote: My daughter was 18 months when I had my double mastectomy and tissue expander placement. It is hard but you can do it. Children get used to it really quickly, you just have to make it clear that you can't pick them up but that they can crawl in your lap. When the baby wants to lay his head on your chest you can have a blanket at hand and put that on your chest first. They will pick up really quickly about what's going on and will find new ways to cuddle and to spend time with you. They will adapt to climbing the stairs and climbing into the crib, they will be helpful when you need to change the diaper. The baby will be even glad to fetch things for you. It will be fine since the baby can get around on their own an come to you. Hugs!
Posts.Title: Bi lateral mastectomy and reconstruction Mondy inks

Posts.Content: May 16, 2015 09:36AM inks wrote: If she is right handed then the right hand is supposed to be stronger. I am not familiar with grip exercises but I think breast cancer surgeries do not affect those muscles. Unless she has lymphedema, I am not familiar with lymphedema. If the arm affected by surgeries is weak it may be time to see physical therapist again. I saw one for the first time couple weeks ago, over a 1.5 years after the surgery, it was very interesting. I hope your wife regains her strenght.
Posts.Title: QUERY many inks

Posts.Content: Sep 8, 2015 07:18AM inks wrote: My endocrinologist considers type 2 diabetes a lifestyle disease and he never referred to any risk % although my grandmother has diabetes, he said that I will avoid diabetes by living a healthy lifestyle. So stats don't mean anything, they just say what % of population under what conditions has the disease. There is nothing you can do about the second hand smoke you were subjected to in childhood and there is nothing you can do about the fact that you got BC. But you can take charge of your health from here on by living a healthy lifestyle.
Posts.Title: Second hand smoke and bc -- 90% risk? EbonyEyes inks

Posts.Content: Sep 8, 2015 12:42PM inks wrote: EbonyEyes - where did I refer to you as being "fat/lazy/self-indulgent" ?????????????? I was only making a reference to a healthy life style. As in if you are concerned about second hand smoke in your childhood the only thing you can do about it now is to avoid second hand smoke. But I am truly sorry that your type 2 diabetes is hereditary and therefore there is nothing you can do about it. But you can read into it however way you choose.
Posts.Title: Second hand smoke and bc -- 90% risk? EbonyEyes inks

Posts.Content: Mar 26, 2015 04:22AM inks wrote: You can drive yourself home just fine they will give you an ice pack and over the counter pain medicine ( I cant remember if it's tylenol or advil, but don't take any at home since one causes bleeding). I could not lift my baby for 2 days after the biopsy. Since it was a consult before biopsy it is weird that the surgeon did not discuss these things with you at the consult. You can change your surgeon after the biopsy if indeed you end up having cancer. But try to stay calm for now and don't jump ahead of things. You should definetly change the surgeon if you biopsy is positive if you are not comfortable with this surgeon since you would be seeing her every 3-6 months for 2 years. Find out what you have first and then look into what you would have to do to treat it. Hugs!

Posts.Content: Apr 16, 2018 09:36AM inks wrote: I am writing on behalf of my friend with IBC. She was DX in the fall of '16, chemo , surgery, but after surgery the cancer returned around the MX scar, so she got more chemo and radiation. While at radiation the cancer started to move to the other breast, biopsy confirmed it was now triple negative and she is back on chemo but still has visible cancer. Only bone and ct scans done and all clear. They have told her that they are not going to operate on the other breast. So is she still considered stage III, just locally advanced and non operable? My question is if her cancer is TN now but original was HR+ should she still be on hormone blockers or not? And should she be on bone meds since she is so high risk for mets? She also had Oncodeep done (similar to Caris and Foundation One) but she has already become resistant to one of the drugs (it worked great in the beginning). The report is suggesting Metformin an Rapamune (same class as Afinitor but a lot cheaper). Has anyone had any experience or maybe even success using non conventional breast cancer drugs after cancer sensitivity testing? She is in Estonia, they have universal health care but a lot of the newer drugs are not covered, so the cost of drugs is crucial. Thank you in advance for any insight you have to offer!
Posts.Title: If you are not Stage IV but have questions, you may post here chrissyb Olma61

Posts.Content: Apr 16, 2018 08:29PM inks wrote: Thanks Shetland Pony, in her case unfortunately chemo has not been too effective and she is grade 3. Her cancer persisted despite the neoadjuvant FEC and Taxotere. She already failed on Halaven and navelbine. She did not tolerate Xeloda. At the moment she is on Carboplatin and Abraxane but they do not seem to be working either. I tried to make an account at the NCCN to see their recommendations but I can't seem to even make an account. I'll try again tomorrow.
Posts.Title: If you are not Stage IV but have questions, you may post here chrissyb Olma61

Posts.Content: Apr 16, 2018 10:29PM inks wrote: She was originally on Tamoxifen. But they did try Faslodex with Arimidex (she had to get the zoladex to be in menopause) too, but during it her breast got worse so they stopped. So that's what's puzzling, should she be on some form of hormone blocker? She paid out of pocket for the cancer sensitivity test and one of the meds that would work for her is Afinitor, but I be it's the cost why she is not getting it. Metformin and Rapamune were options too, and they are way cheaper, Rapamune is also an MTOR inhibitor just like Afinitor so I'm hoping she could try that. She is going for chemo on Wednesday so I hope she can talk to her doctor. Her report has the part about genes, and somebody handwrote next to ERBB2 - HER2. But the report must have been in color and I only have the black and white version since it talks about highlighted and non highlighted genes. So I have no clue what that means. But I'll tell her to ask her doctor if that would give her a treatment option. I already checked the clinical trials for her and there are none that are recruiting. And she has been told that she will not get surgery. Which I do not understand again.

Posts.Content: Jun 6, 2015 04:43AM inks wrote: Two different cancer centers staged my multifocal and multicentric cancer differently. One went by the size of the largest tumor the other one counted some of the lesions in a lump since there was not enough healthy tissue between them. If there is at least 0.2-0.5cm of healthy tissue between the tumors then the tumors are mesured separately.
Posts.Title: How is BC staged when you have multiple tumors? jmute Ridley

Posts.Content: Jun 20, 2014 08:33AM inks wrote: I am not an expert on familial breast cancer but I am BRCA+ and I know that they recommend surveillance/prevention for BRCA+ 10 years before the youngest relative got cancer. So based on this since your mom got cancer at 40 your risk would be higher when you turn 30. Breast cancer is very rare in people your age especially without BRCA. I hope you have some hormonal changes or cysts. Good luck for your appointment!
Posts.Title: what are the odds... kelmarie87 farmerlucy

Posts.Content: Jun 8, 2015 07:14PM inks wrote: I hope it's nothing and your biopsy is benign. My radiologist also just told that I had solid mass and did not mention the lymph nodes or the rest of my tumors. But I got the biopsy on the same day. Most breast biopsies are benign so try to take it easy until you get your results. Worrying will not change the outcome of things but it will make you miserable. Hugs!

There was a large Canadian study published in FebruaryÂ about BRCA mutation and the timing of oophorectomy and the recommendation for BRCA2 was to have it at age 40, since only 1 woman in the study with BRCA2 had ovarian cancer before age 50. It sure is a lot of important decisions in a very short time. I got my exercises from theÂ breast surgeon, they are just the regular ones found everywhere. The treatment is the same weather you are rich or poor and is very straight forward, sometimes the oncologist seem to be robotic with breast cancer. The oncologist will most likely decide if your mom will need chemo and/or hormone therapy. Just because you are dealing with a place that treats uninsured patients does not mean you are getting substandard care. I wish your mom the best!

Posts.Content: May 5, 2015 05:50PM inks wrote: So sorry you have to be in here. I was 36 as well when I was diagnosed. Why are they doing an excisional biopsy? Have they tried stereotactic or MRI assisted biopsy first? Excisional biopsies are not that common anymore. I would not want two surgeries if that was me, that's a lot of strain on your body for no good reason. Are you at a large center and does your surgeon do only breast surgeries? It's uncommon to see an oncologist prior to biopsy. Try to go to a larger breast center if you can to make sure you would not have to have unneccesary procedures.

Posts.Content: May 5, 2015 06:49PM inks wrote: Even with a large tumor this does not make sense. Excisional biopsy - essentially a lumpectomy followed by a mastectomy a week later. Are 2 surgeries back to back really necessary. Surgery has side effects that are not great if you have cancer - the possible release of growth factors related to surgical wounding and the immunosuppression caused by surgery and anesthesia. Would she not need chemo after the biopsy rather than a mastectomy. Maybe there is more to it that we do not know?

Posts.Content: May 24, 2014 03:20PM inks wrote: Did they biopsy any of your lymph nodes prior to chemo? I had a micromet in my lymphnode and the size of my tumor is complicated. Since it's multifocal they can measure it all as one which makes me 5+cm, or they can go by the largest 2.1cm. One of the ROs that I consulted told that she would have recommended radiation even without my lymph node. I had LVI and necrosis too. Both ROs recommended radiation also because of my age (37) so I did it mainly because if I were to get a chest wall recurrence the outlook would be pretty bad. IMRT radiation is a little better at sparing the heart so try to consult with an RO that can provide that. If you are on the fence about rads go get a second opinion and ask what are the reasons they would or would not recommend radiation. I felt better about my decision after talking to 2 ROs. Â Radiation was not as bad as I thought it would be.

Posts.Title: Found 4 lumps... kimber9826 kimber9826

Posts.Content: Oct 14, 2016 09:18PM inks wrote: Yes it is possible to have breast cancer while breast feeding. I found my lump when I had stopped breast feeding. I think it's great that you are having it checked out. If you are breast feeding they prefer that you pump or feed your baby right before mammogram or ultrasound. It sounds that you will have fine needle aspiration, where they will try to suck some cells into a syringe to be tested. The core needle biopsy that I had was no biggie, they gave me an ice pack and told to take ibuprofen. Depending on what side your suspicious spot is you may want to have someone else to drive you, the seat belt may feel uncomfortable. I drove myself and I was fine. The problem will be picking up the baby afterwards, they do not want you to lift anything heavier than a gallon of milk. Do not stop breastfeeding until you get your biopsy results. Hugs to you and your little one! Fingers grossed your lump will be benign!

Posts.Title: Confirmed BC today and having bilateral mastectomy next week AngelLynn inks

Posts.Content: Dec 17, 2015 12:53PM inks wrote: If your SBR score is 9 out of 9 then it means grade 3. But HR- is often grade 3 already, but your tumor is really small if it's less than 1cm. Lumpectomy with radiation is equal to mastectomy and the lumpectomy recommendation has nothing to do with having HMO (radiation is rather expensive too). You could ask about neoadjuvant chemo (chemo before surgery) since if tumor does not respond to chemo you could get more chemo after the surgery. The new recommendation is that if there is not complete pathologic response you could get more carboplatin. And also make sure they give you platinum based chemo since you are HR-. Ask when you will find out the HER results. Hang in there!
Posts.Title: Waiting MRI results bllshane bllshane

Posts.Content: May 20, 2015 09:35PM inks wrote: I had lymphnodes that were enlarged on my neck, the surgeon said that since they were on the opposite side from my cancer it would be unlikely that it was cancer. Later it turned out that I had a rash on my scalp near my ear, once I treated it with steroids the lymphnodes disappeared. I hope yours turn out to be nothing worrisome.
Posts.Title: neck lymph nodes after dcis and radiation lisa9101 inks

Posts.Content: Jan 15, 2016 09:34PM inks wrote: I am BRCA1+ and at the time of my bilateral mastectomies they did the sentinel node biopsy on both sides. BRCA mutation raises the risk of contralateral BC by 40% so in my opinion this is very different from your regular average run of the mill prophylactic mastectomy. There were studies about BRCA+ prophylactic mastectomies and weather the sentinel node biopsy was beneficial and the recommendation for prophylactic (no prior cancer history) mastectomies in BRCA carries was that sentinel node biopsy is not necessary. However I was not able to find any conclusive info about BRCA and the need of sentinel node biopsy in the non cancer breast. In my own case the sentinel node biopsy on my prophylactic side gave me cording and the scar is way longer on that side. This area has very little research and the decision is going to be hard for you.
Posts.Title: Sentinel node dissection for prophlactic mastectomy? lemonadehk lemonadehk

And I assume these nodes did not pop up when they did your breast biopsy and ultrasound? This could mean that the nodes are simply reacting to the breast biopsy. I hope you find out soon either way. Posts.Title: 37yrs old just Diagnose MoHoff78 Nini78

Posts.Content: Nov 2, 2013 04:35PM inks wrote: I had a mastectomy and in the operating room they found nothing in the sentinel nodes. Later the pathology came back with two micromets in one node. They were 0.2 and 0.07. My surgeon really did not want to subject me to ALND. He took my case to the "roundtable" and only one oncologist insisted on ALND because she said it could change the treatment. My current oncologist was not there but he was against ALND also. I had an enlarged sentinel node prior to surgery that showed up on the MRI, but oncologist said it could have been from the biopsy. And the pathology report did not explain if it was the enlarged node that had the micromets. I feel comfortable with no ALND the chemo should zap anything else. My grandmother has lymphedema and although it is not the end of the world it is definitely not comfortable.
Posts.Title: Micromet in Sentinal Node: Anyone else? Runningfromcancer SuC

Posts.Content: Nov 2, 2015 07:57PM inks wrote: Better wait for pathology results and see what the other tumor is. Sometimes they are not similar, some women have both ductal and lobular cancers, different HER status. Your stage and treatment will be based on the larger tumor (unless of course the smaller one is HER+). Fingers crossed that they are similar and you can skip chemo.
Posts.Title: Was stage 1....second lump found in mastectomy.... hughesy84 dtad

Posts.Content: Sep 5, 2016 09:10AM inks wrote: I did not have seroma but have cording on my prophylactic MX side. You can do stretching exercises until you can see a physical therapist. Any stretching just a little to where you will feel the pain will help. You will see noticeable difference if you do the stretching 3 times a day, your pain will lessen and you will regain range of motion. My PT did not break my cording, he said it's enough to just have it stretched to the max to where it does not hurt. Even after PT the cording may keep coming back several times. I sleep my arm straight up under my pillow whenever I feel the cording again. You arm will feel better if you are religious about the exercises. I hope you get to PT soon.

Posts.Title: Breast indentation Matty_35 Busymum2015

Posts.Content: May 1, 2014 05:33PM inks wrote: So sorry that your doctors can not offer you a explanation for your enlarged lymph node. What doctors are you seeing? Was the ultrasound done by a breast specialist? My lymph node was enlarged in ultrasound and MRI, I ended up with micromets in the lymph node but I never found out if it was the enlarged lymph node that had them. My grandmother had cancer only in her lymph node but I have no idea how that would look on a ultrasound. You at least deserve an explanation from your doctors.
Posts.Title: Confusing ultrasound chris02 inks

Posts.Content: May 2, 2014 08:02PM inks wrote: I had the enlarged lymph node in the ultrasound and MRI (my lumps/cancer was visible in both US and MRI). But they could not confirm that the lymph node had cancer without a lymph node biopsy. The surgeon did not want the lymph node biopsied and in hindsight it probably would not have shown cancer since it was only a micromet and isolated tumor cells. Even right after surgery I was declared node negative. When the final pathology came it had the micromet and isolated tumor cells. So in my case there was such a low volume of cancer in the lymph node that the US and MRI were not conclusive. I think it's great that you had the US done at a breast center since they are a higher volume facility and see all sorts of things. Maybe you can get another mammogram and ultrasound in 3 months if you still have the lump and enlarged lymph node. I still find it weird that they can't explain your lymph node.
Posts.Title: Confusing ultrasound chris02 inks

Posts.Content: Dec 20, 2014 12:03PM inks wrote: You are definitely in the grey zone with grade 2, Oncotype and a micromet. In order to make your decision you should involve some other factors too. Were you just multifocal or were you both multicentric and multifocal? What is your age? It is known that sometimes the only benefit from chemo is menopause, so you could look into ovarian supression either with tamoxifen or an AI. Would a milder chemo be an option? Will you get radiation for the micromet in lymphnode? It's a tough descision and either way there are no guarantees.
